reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qq0a2piTbJA
SECTOR is a FPS game created by Airys Software.
SECTOR is made with FPS creator.
FPS Creator is an easy to use game maker. You can make a shooter in minutes and you can expand it with extra model packs."
So estimated development time: 1-3 weeks.

When I mentioned that they made SECTOR with FPS creator in steam discussions
date:
they immediately deleted it. While threads that directly insult the developer or called his game ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• remains intact (which is a good thing). Thankfully they can't delete reviews.

I promised the developer to make a walkthrough video of his game because there were no gameplay videos or let's plays of his game. And the official trailer was bad with huge ACTION! watermark on it (the trailer has been removed). So he provided me a steam key of his game.

SECTOR is a hard game. Enemies have pin-point accuracy
recommended: sometimes they get bugged and shoot rapidly which causes immediate death. SECTOR does not have auto-save
hoursPlayed: so you have to save manually. Sometimes there will be locked doors and you have to literally search every corner of the room in-order to find it
voteText: key searching will eat most of your time. SECTOR does not have any graphics options
helpfulPercent: so if you get FPS drops then tough luck. Sometimes when you load a save
votesHelpful: you will immediately die on spawn for no reason
votesTotal: that means you have to use an older save. If you managed to reach as far as me (level 5) then this is your dead-end. "Crates and barrels puzzle" part cannot be completed because of the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• FPSC physics engine. In other FPSC games
votesFunny: they only stick to 3 crates stacking
column16: but still manageable. I contacted the developer about this part hoping that he replaces it with a simple stair or elevator
column17: here is his response:\nOriginally posted by Airys Software:Hello

column22:
that is sure we finished the game a lot of times to test it.

I played a lot of FPS creator games and made some myself. SECTOR is entry-level FPSC game with a price tag slapped on it. SECTOR costed $5 at first

reviewText: Still wandering the level.  It works just like an FPS Creator/GameGuru quickie prototype, but not like a game you should pay money for.  I have nothing against games created with the revamped FPS Creator engine.  I have something against bad games that have nothing new to offer and act as obvious cash-grabs in an attempt to cover base development engine package acquisition costs.\n\nAvoid.

It's a shame, because the game itself, while simple, isn't terrible otherwise.

reviewText:
Wow, this is the most difficult game ever created - most underrated FPS on steam and it's only 6,99! 6,99! [WorthABuy reference intended]
Okay guys, let's cut the crab...
This is an insult. It's downright awful and I cannot barely understand how this could have possibly been released on steam. They have to get their quality management right. I will stop the rage now and give some reasons.
First off, there is NO options menu. There are no options whatsoever! No resolution, no bindable keys, N.o.t.h.i.n.g.
There is no introduction, no tutorial, nothing that would qualify this as a game title. Note: I will not get into the FPS creator debate that is taking place in the community. But: The game actually is made with FPS creator, the models prove it.
I could list numerous things that would convince the very rest of you, but only some extra info:
It doesn't even matter if you aim or not. The crosshair stays the same, the only thing that changes is that the weapon's model becomes centered and obscures the view - Period.
I will stop here.
Thanks for your attention.
Yours,
B.

reviewText:
The store description informs us, from what I can translate of the broken English it's written in, that we are Dimitri and that we're in big trouble since the scientific experiments we were working on have broken loose and taken control of the station.
Well, too bad there's no trace of this story in the game and that SECTOR itself looks and plays like a bad amateurish project made with a smattering of generic assets thrown together.

PROS:

-I honestly can't think of any

CONS:

-bad graphics with blurry textures, jagged edges everywhere, unrealistic lightning and amateurish weapon effects

-very few sounds, what's there is basic, weak or downright horrible: also no soundtrack

-the puzzle sections include pixel hunting tiny objects, stacking barrels or crates that will easily bug and fall or trying to move large objects away from a wall using the awkward controls

-laughable gunplay, the weapons look bad, sound worse, have no ironsights (the ironsight view is just a zoom) and slowly fire weak lasers

-basic enemy AI, they just fire and charge at you

-bad level design, it's basically large rooms contaning the few assets used by the game (skeletons, boxes or pipes) connected by empty corridors

-no way to change graphics or controls, heck the game doesn't even explain key bindings and I had to look on the forums

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=523218403

My first time with SECTOR was me spending 20 minutes walking through empty rooms trying to find a key, I eventually found Jim Sterling's video that pointed me the right way: said key was as grey as the floor and lying half-hidden near a corner: this wasn't fun and paved the way for the rest of the insipid gameplay to come.

While the store page boasts about this being an homage to the hardcore FPS games of the 90s don't be fooled: there's no story, the enemies are stupid, the puzzles are either frustrating or downright broken and the actual game is hard just due to the bad gunplay: the production values are also so low to make SECTOR look and sound worse than the games it's supposed to copy.

Stay away from this, even if you get this from a bundle- like me- there's no reason to even install or try it.

reviewText:
SECTOR is apparently a FPS game that was released in mid 2015 from the folks at UD and published by Airys Software. After enjoying some hate and low sales, as well as publishers not being able to contact developers for some reason, it went Free To Play at early 2016. At least from what I understand. It was a game that got through Steam Greenlight and from what I heard uses FPS Creator engine and some assets. Well, that sure isn't a good start.

Technically, it's pure awfulness. No options. Never save while forced to crouch. You will get stuck. It will crash on loading. Keep few saves, sometimes you die by loading some savepoints. And look, this game is a glitch, so.

Upon learning that this game had only 9 levels, I started my quest by launching the game. Immeditly I was thrown into main menu, which had only New Game, Loading and Quit Game. No Options. Ever. Some ambient generator sound that looped horribly was playing. I clicked New Game and was thrown into first level. No plot. No music. No explanations. Dark. This world is dead. Level 1.

After walking through two big rooms, last one having skeleton resting against pipe, I picked up key without noticing it by just wandering around. As I would later find out, keys in general are black tiny pieces of turd that are almost impossible to see with the Doom-3-made-awful lighting that this game has. They are sure to be pain to find. After that, opening door with ENTER, I picked up pistol and in next big room I got to fight a single enemy.

Where I found out that combat in this game sucks. Your movement is clunky, the weapons are clunky, enemies are 100% accurate hitscan shooters who just charge at you. And they are clunky. And have no painstates. It's as primitive and unfun as it gets. There also was random NPC who had enemy skin on him, just standing there and shaking head in disbilief.

On level 2, having solved the puzzle-thing and crawling through the overly long shaft because staring at wall texture for minute is fun, I got out into room, with new sucky weapons. There were more enemies, shooting and skeletons. This is where I found out that you can lean around with Q and E. Or more exactly that most enemies don't awake if you lean around corner and shoot them, which is the way I beat most of the game without pain.

Until I went to level 3 and game crashed there. Sighing, I reloaded my save and sighed again, as I found myself outside of level geometry with no way in. Never save in shafts.

Level 3 was funky. One of the soldiers didn't attack me and instead yelled at my something like a commander when I came close. He was too adorable to shoot at in this dead world. I didn't find key, but I found place where I managed to activate switch through the wall. Or ceiling. I don't know by now. By the end of level I found a skeleton. Mr. Skeleton got tired of acting dead in this game. He was standing and chilling like NPC, his favourite drink was placed on a pipe nearby. Even he didn't care about this game anymore. He was drunk.

I don't remember where, but in level 3 or 4 I found shotgun. It's the only good weapon because it either kills instantly or at least knocks them back, stunning for a bit. It's also the only weapon where iron sight works, as it tightens the arc at which pellet spread up, defying the real life logic.

Level 4 had rooms with open ceiling, you could see the sky there. But it was grey, flat and the base was as dark as ever even under the sky. The whole universe was dead and had no soul. There was a room with BSOD computer, broom. It was room with open ceiling too, with useless air shaft nearby. I also saw stairs that I couldn't reach above. As it would later turn out, devs wanted me to build stairs out of wooden boxes, but I already destroyed them all. Never destroy boxes, they hold nothing. Thankfully, engine's player movement sucked and I was able to get there by ramming and jumping nearby fence.

Level 5 had water. And green light. And no one to listen to your whines. This is where I researched and found a way to grab boxes in FPS Creator engine. Right mouse click works, but you have to pull away" weapon by pressing same slot number. Weapon will remain
date: but it will show "0/0" ammo. If you don't do it
recommended: then you can still hold the objects but game will glitch out and you will not be able to switch weapons. One reviewer said that it's impossible to get out from water. But with my experience of awful game
hoursPlayed: I bet on the awful player physics again and succeed by placing three boxes in corner of a room and spammed the jump button while ramming them.\n\nLevel 6 and level 7 mixed around in my memory. There was nothing good to talk about. Or nothing special. My brain already wants to block this. But I think that there was lab theme and skeletons. In one of them there was a shaft almost-maze section. And one of the side dead ends there had a skeleton with red lamp between his lovely legs. Upon recognising my body
voteText: I went to check if he has something and I got pushed on top of level geometry of the shaft by his collision. Thanks again
helpfulPercent: Mr Skeleton.\n\nLevel 8 was hospital-lab themed. There was a real human corpse on a single sit. Wandering more

reviewText:
When you launch the game you arrive on a very simple menu. Instead of music you get to listen to a loop of a robotic cat purring.

Click New Game.

You start out in a dimly lit hallway. There is no introduction or tutorial or even bubble tips. Use WASD to walk around, only to discover you're some deformed bipedal creature (Dimitri according to the game description) with a severe limp (judging by the highly irregular footsteps) and probably a large hump on your shoulder, I imagine. Anyway, you walk through the hallway and come upon a large room, empty aside from a large box. Then you come upon another empty room, another hallway, and more empty rooms and hallways. In each one, someone has methodically lifted the floor tiles in the same pattern.

Finally you come to a room with several doors. You can't open any of them, I tried literally every key on the keyboard. I did discover some new moves, though. With Q and E you can snap your head from side to side at horrifying speeds, and with C you can instantly drop your head on the floor. Neat. The , and . buttons also adjust the gamma from lighting glitch to full sunlight radiating from the closed doors, with film noir somewhere in between.

After being frustrated by trying to open these doors, you move on through the hallway only to find another door. Upon approaching this one you are given a tip that the door is locked and you need a key to open it. I can only assume this is the end of the game and that I have won, as there is literally nothing else I can do. I rock at FPS games and I have placed the order on the earth. Go me!

reviewText: First of all, this game can't be beaten.  When I got to Level 4, I found that the key I collected doesn't open any door or passage.  I got so frustrated at this game, that I developed a splitting headache by the end of my playthrough.  I played about 2 hours over the course of yesterday and today.  I played as much as I could complete and as much as I could stand.  Let's get into some details.\n\nThe gameplay is pretty generic, almost boring at times.  It feels slow and sluggish, even though you can run".  The enemies in this game are much too difficult for this kind of game; they're sparse
date: but they're too accurate and too powerful.  I think the reason is because the developers didn't know how to make proper enemy AI that's neither overpowering nor simple-minded.\n\nThe gun selection is standard for a game like this.  Most of the weapons were pretty tough to use because most of them were pretty ineffectual.  The shotgun was the only weapon that was decent.  However
recommended: there are a lot of problems with the gun mechanics.  For example
hoursPlayed: there's a delay with switching guns.  Also
voteText: you can only switch guns while standing still.  However

votesHelpful: at least in the part of the game I played.  I don't know if this is a mechanic for another part of the game or a half-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• mechanic the developers never finished or even implemented.  All I know is that it's a completely useless "feature".  On a side note

Making the keys and floors a similar texture and color didn't help me get through the levels.  It also didn't help that the lighting only worked properly some of the time.  However

reviewText: This game is horrific. People actually paid for this? Seriously? First of all the menu is a mess, options are mislabeled. I spent a few minutes at the menu screen because I didn't realize that the miscolored loading" label actually meant "load game". No options either
recommended: more importantly NO KEYBINDING INFO. I couldn't figure out what the "use" key was. This along with no feedback makes it impossible to tell what key does what. I stood in front of a door hitting each key to figure out what the "use" key was with no effect. Took a while to realize that it was an unopenable door that didn't react. Helpfully the "press enter to use" subtitle came up
hoursPlayed: after you had to hit enter to progress to that stage. Animations are nonexistant. It's like no effort was put into actually playing the game before releasing it.\n\ntl;dr It's like what I would expect from someone who ran through a Unity tutorial
